questions.title: Teens' Opinions on Social Media
questions.description: Between 2017 and 2018, researchers at Common Sense Media surveyed over 3,000 teens from around the United States. We asked them how they felt about technology and social media. What did teens have to say? See if you can guess!

imageMetadata.resources:
2018: Social Media, Social Life: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/sites/default/files/uploads/research/2018-social-media-social-life-executive-summary-web.pdf
2017: Quarterly Survey Series - Social Media Disconnect: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/sites/default/files/uploads/research/commonsense-surveymonkey_teeninternetuse-topline_release.pdf

2017: Quarterly Survey Series - Social Media Disconnect: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/sites/default/files/uploads/research/commonsense-surveymonkey_teeninternetuse-topline_release.pdf

questions.question: What percentage of teens said that they'd deleted a social media post because it got too few "likes"?
Among teens on Instagram, what percentage said that they follow celebrities?
What percentage of teens said they were "extremely" or "very concerned" about fake influencer accounts?

questions.title: Now it's your turn.
questions.description: In the following polls, you can share your opinions on these issues. After responding, start a conversation with some classmates or friends. Did you agree or disagree with each statement? Why, or why not?

questions.question: It's important to be careful about what you post on social media.
Some people think too much about their social media posts, and are always trying to be "perfect."
It's OK to post a version of yourself on social media that's not 100% "real."

questions.title: Want to learn more?
questions.description: Many digital citizenship issues don't have clear, right-or-wrong answers. But you can learn more by starting conversations with your classmates and friends. And for more free resources, visit us at commonsense.org/digital-citizenship.
